This is a really great Half-Life spin-off, showing the Black Mesa incident again, but on Barney's point of view. The game is generally really enjoyable, and I consider it definitely better than HL:Opposing Force.

I should probably note that I cheesed in some parts of the game by doing bhop or launching myself in the air with bombs because I couldn't find a way to solve some problems (or most likely couldn't find the solution because I'm dumb)

N√£o tem chef√µes nesse jogo, o que √© um ponto negativo vendo que ele √© feito pela Gearbox, a mesma que fez Opposing Force, que n√£o √© t√£o grande quando o Half Life 1, mas √© igualmente completo quanto a armas e ter um chef√£o. As armas s√£o outro ponto negativo, s√£o as mesmas que vimos em Half Life. 
Um outra coisa que me incomoda s√£o os jumpscares, ele tem MUITOS, mas MUITO mesmo. Em Half Life eles s√£o colocados em pontos estrat√©gicos que fazem sentido, j√° em Blue Shift eles s√£o colocados em qualquer lugar, e que fica na cara que √© s√≥ pro momento "Pegadinha do Mario Games!", as vezes previs√≠veis, mas tome cuidado com os cantos estreitos seguidos de curvas.
No geral √© uma expans√£o sem coisas novas, curta, mas ainda sim divertida. Os seus erros s√£o mais pela repeti√ß√£o de coisas e falta de novidades. Mesmo assim recomendo, j√° que comprar o pacote com o Half Life e suas DLCs n√£o √© t√£o caro, e te da mais conte√∫do desse jogo. Jogue sem medo!

I wish Steam had a "mixed" option for reviews cause that's about what I'd give Blue Shift. Blue Shift is a pretty fun, but short and bite-sized expansion to Half-Life. This is more understandable when you know that this was originally supposed to be apart of the cancelled SEGA Dreamcast port for Half-Life. Nontheless, I only have this due to buying the Half-Life complete bundle, and I'd recommend that's where you get it to. Blue Shift is not, in my opinion, worth the money by itself. I'm still gonna give it a "Yes" recommendation because it's not bad by any means, but it's doesn't really expand on Half-Life all that much like Opposing Force did. Also the game has no real "final boss", I won't spoil the ending but don't expect to be fighting the Ninilanth or anything like that.

Though I'm gonna have to deduct a few points because this expansion brought along with it the horribly cursed HD model pack.

Cheers.

A fun yet forgettable experience.

Half-life: Blue Shift takes 1-2 hours to beat and is the shortest of the three games that are available on steam.

Due to the decrease in length the game isn't as jam packed as Half-Life or it's for expansion Opposing Force. 

Blue Shift features less weapons than the original game and no new weapons for this game or from Opposing Force; All the weapons featured in this game are basic guns so you wont be using the Gluon gun or the TAU-Canon. 

There's also no memorable moments such as launching a rocket, being left behind by your HECU comrades, fighting a giant fetus, fighting a giant ballsack and you get it by now.

Another problem coming from this game is the lack of new enemies, either original or returning from Opposing Force; Released two years after the first expansion you would expect a longer more expanded game that fleshes out the Half-Life universe in terms of characters, locations and enemies but this game delivers on none of that since this games main supporting character Dr.Rosenberg was featured one year earlier in the PS2 expansion Half-Life: Decay.

Ultimately this game is disappointing after playing Half-Life and Opposing Force, but at the end of the day it's more Half-Life.

Half Life Blue Shift is the second main expansion to Half Life. This part of the HL1 saga puts you in the shoes of Barney Calhoun, everyone's favorite Black Mesa security guard who plays a more prominent role as one of the loveable characters of Half Life 2 in that game. But this expansion is a bit of a step down compared to Opposing force. It's still a very solid expansion, but worse nontheless. The role of a security guard is a less interesting perspective than the previous two, and there aren't really any new weapons or enemies introduced. Towards the end of the campaign you also visit Xen, but it's a lot more bearable than in the first game because it removes a lot of the annoying platforming. Despite some of the obvious similarities, it maintains the amazing worldbuilding, atmosphere, puzzles, and music that you can expect in a Half Life game. So if you're a fan of classic goldsource Half Life games then this should provide a short and sweet little taste of that for you, that I can easily reccommend to FPS fans.
Cool little Half-Life DLC that's practically over in a flash. You can do a lot worse for the asking price!
